Jason,
 
What I meant to say was: Isn't the outcome of the probability of c=
rossover
...
 
I just woke up and read this thread.  I forgot the rule not =
to answer e-mail
without coffee.
 
Ken


  _____  

From: neat@yahoogroups.=
com [mailto:neat@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
Kenneth Lloyd
Sent: Monday, =
November 10, 2008 7:31 AM
To: neat@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [neat] Re: =
Crossover doing anything in HyperNEAT and PNEAT?





Jason,
 
Isn't the pr=
obability of crossover a Dirac delta?  Meaning that crossover
may not be pe=
rformed on each gene?
 
Ken


  _____  

From: neat@yahoogroups.com [mailto=
:neat@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Jason
Gauci
Sent: Monday, November 10, =
2008 7:17 AM
To: neat@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [neat] Re: Crossover doing a=
nything in HyperNEAT and PNEAT?



Initial results from running with crosso=
ver working as you described
look worse than with the old way; however, I t=
hink that the mutation
rates need to be tweaked because now mutations in in=
dividuals quickly
spread throughout the species.

I'm going to try to play =
with the mutation rates and see if I can get
it to work better, but I think=
 it might actually work better without
performing crossover on each gene.

=
I'll let you know what I find out.

Jason G.

 To: "neat@yahoogroups. <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com> com"

> > Subject: [neat] Re: Crossover=
 doing anything in HyperNEAT and PNEAT?
> > 
> > The question about crossov=
er in NEAT is interesting. Although it does
> > not provide a huge boost in=
 performance, it is still a significant
> > advance compared to what came b=
efore in neuroevolution, which is why
> > it is still a payoff. The competi=
ng conventions problem (also called
> > the "topology matching problem") wa=
s a huge issue in neuroevolution
> > before NEAT, and because of it some re=
searchers were questioning
> > whether there was any hope for crossover at =
all in such systems. It
> > could be shown in prior systems without histori=
cal marking that
> > crossover actually hurts the evolution of neural netwo=
rks, making its
> > prospects dim. Angeline and Pollack even introduced a n=
euroevolution
> > method called GNARL (before NEAT) that didn't even have c=
rossover as
> > an operator because of the concern. In this context, NEAT m=
ade
> > crossover safe for neuroevolution and removed its stigma in such
> =
> systems. That is, it switched it from a liability to an advantage
> > tha=
t boosts performance a bit in NEAT. So it's an advance in that
sense.
> > 
=
> > However, while the "bit" of performance gain (vs. having no crossover)
=
> > *is* likely statistically significant, it is not huge. The real
> > ben=
efit of historical markings
> > is that it enables speciation, which does h=
ave a dramatic effect
> > because of protecting innovation to support compl=
exification.
> > Crossover is more like icing on the cake. However, I think=
 many
> > people identify NEAT with crossover because it is such a clear
> =
> demonstration of the benefit of historical markings. In that sense,
> > i=
t is perhaps conceptually more significant than it is functionally.
> > Sti=
ll, I would recommend keeping it if you can, since it does appear
> > to be=
 better to have it than not, albeit not enormously.
> > 
> > ken
> > 
> > -=
-- In neat@yahoogroups. <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com> com, Jeff Clune

been shown to provide a huge payoff. If crossover doesn't help

h

(i.e.

ut if

either

e if

. I am confident that HyperNEAT 2.5 chooses the

> >>>>> outside

> >>>>> packages,

 >>>>>> instead of one or the other. I can go check those packages, of

eads.

se you must
> > ensure
> >>>>>>> that individuals should not mate with them=
selves or such
ones that
> >>>>>>> have zero compatibility distance. Or at =
least try a few hundred
> >>> times
> >>>>>>> to find a different mate :) H=
ey, I say this to all users.
> > Don't use
> >>>>>>> rand(), fuck that, use=
 the Mersenne Twister instead. I noticed
> >>> that in
> >>>>>>> enhances p=
erformance!
> >>>>>>

ns, though. I will delve into them

> >>>>>>>>> Well I don't know about the exact implementati=
ons of
> > HyperNEAT you
> >>>>>>> are
> >>>>>>>>> using (note that P-NEAT =
is just NEAT with additive mutations
> >>>>>>>>> disabled), but in principl=
e crossover should choose genes
> > randomly
> >>>>>>>>> from both parents =
as it builds the offspring genome, the
> > child. In
> >>>>>>>>> HyperNEAT =
the crossover is different, there you actually do a
> >>>>>>> regular
> >>>=
>>>>>> NEAT evolution of networks that build other networks based
> > on th=
e
> >>>>>>>>> substrate configuration. That is, you only mate and mutate th=
e
> >>>>>>> CPPNs.
> >>>>>>>>> But in the case you get lots of individuals =
with equal
> > fitness, I
> >>>>>>>>> guess these individuals are clones. P=
erhaps the code
frequently
> >>>>>>>>> chooses the same individuals for mat=
ing? You can try to
> > avoid this
> >>>>>>> by
> >>>>>>>>> introducing a l=
oop in which you try candidates for a
> > "father" that
> >>>>>>> are
> >>>=
>>>>>> not compatible with the mother, that is, when their
> > compatibilit=
y
> >>>>>>>>> distance is 0.00, try again. There is another possibility,
> =
> simply
> >>>>>>>>> every mutation disturbs the CPPN and therefore the pro=
duced
> >>>>>>> network is
> >>>>>>>>> changed in such a magnitude that is =
has no chance for
> > survival and
> >>>>>>> is
> >>>>>>>>> discarded. Even=
 though there is speciation.
> >>>>>>>>> 
> >>>>>>>>> Peter
> >>>>>>>>> 
> =
>>>>>>>>> 
> >>>>>>>>> --- In neat@yahoogroups. <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.=
com> com,
Jeff Clune <jclune@> wrote:
> >>>>>>>>>> 
> >>>>>>>>>> Hello all-=

> >>>>>>>>>> 
> >>>>>>>>>> Does crossover do anything in PNEAT and HyperNE=
AT?
> >>>>>>>>>> 
> >>>>>>>>>> PNEAT:
> >>>>>>>>>> If I am reading the code=
 correctly, during crossover, if the
> >>>>>>>>> substrates are
> >>>>>>>>>=
> the same (i.e. all links have the same ID), which is
always the
> >>>>>>>=
 case
> >>>>>>>>> in
> >>>>>>>>>> P-NEAT, *all* of the link values are take=
n from either
> > parent1 or
> >>>>>>>>> parent2.
> >>>>>>>>>> Isn't it mor=
e normal when crossing over to take some from
> > parent1
> >>>>>>>>> and s=
ome
> >>>>>>>>>> from parent2? Why grab all from just one?
> >>>>>>>>>> 
> =
>>>>>>>>>> This means that in PNEAT crossover does nothing, right?
It will
=
> >>>>>>>>> always grab
> >>>>>>>>>> the substrate of parent1 or the substr=
ate of parent2. If I
> > track
> >>>>>>>>> parent and
> >>>>>>>>>> offsprin=
g fitness, 100% of the time the child has the exact
> > same
> >>>>>>>>> fi=
tness as
> >>>>>>>>>> one of the two parents.
> >>>>>>>>>> 
> >>>>>>>>>> On=
 to HyperNEAT:
> >>>>>>>>>> 
> >>>>>>>>>> I tracked the fitness of each par=
ent and the resulting
> > offspring.
> >>>>>>>>> The odd
> >>>>>>>>>> thing=
 is that the organisms that are crossed only (i.e.
> > they are
> >>>>>>>>>=
 never
> >>>>>>>>>> mutated) have the *exact* same fitness of one of their
=
parents
> >>>>>>>>> 98.88% of the
> >>>>>>>>>> time. In 20 runs, that was o=
nly 136 orgs out of 12257
that were
> >>>>>>>>> crossed over
> >>>>>>>>>> a=
nd not mutated. That seems wrong, doesn't it? Why would
these
> >>>>>>> new=

> >>>>>>>>> links
> >>>>>>>>>> have such a small impact? It turns out that=
 this is because
> >>>>>>> nearly
> >>>>>>>>> every
> >>>>>>>>>> time that =
there is an extra link that gets placed in the
child,
> >>>>>>> the
> >>>>>=
>>>> parent
> >>>>>>>>>> that donated that link is also the parent whose we=
ights are
> > being
> >>>>>>>>> grabbed,
> >>>>>>>>>> meaning that the cros=
sover is only copying the parent
> > (hence the
> >>>>>>>>> same
> >>>>>>>>=
>> fitness). It seems to me that crossover should be much more
> >>>>>>>>> =
disruptive, no?
> >>>>>>>>>> 
> >>>>>>>>>> 
> >>>>>>>>>> As a final test, I=
 did a set of hyperneat and pneat runs
> > with the
> >>>>>>>>> default
> >=
>>>>>>>>> 'MutateOnlyProbability' parameter set to .25, so 25% of orgs
> >>=
>>>>> never
> >>>>>>>>> are
> >>>>>>>>>> candidates for crossover. I then r=
an experimental treatments
> >>>>>>>>>> hyperneat-noCross and pneat-noCross=
 where the
> >>>>>>> MutateOnlyProbability
> >>>>>>>>>> parameter was set t=
o 1, so no orgs were crossed over.
> > Despite my
> >>>>>>>>> comments
> >>=
>>>>>>>> above, Hyperneat (with cross) did beat HyperNEAT-noCross,
> > howe=
ver
> >>>>>>>>> the
> >>>>>>>>>> difference was not tremendous (although it=
 does seem to be
> >>>>>>>>> statistically
> >>>>>>>>>> significant). For p=
-neat, the reverse was true. Nevertheless,
> >>>>>>> this
> >>>>>>>>> is no=
t a
> >>>>>>>>>> perfect test of whether crossover pays dividends, because =
if
> >>>>>>>>> crossover does
> >>>>>>>>>> nothing most of the time, and I =
increase
MutateOnlyProbability
> >>>>>>> from
> >>>>>>>>> .25 to
> >>>>>>>>=
>> 1, I have effectively raised the mutation rate (only 80% of
> >>>>>>> cr=
ossed
> >>>>>>>>> orgs are
> >>>>>>>>>> also mutated).
> >>>>>>>>>> 
> >>>>=
>>>>>> Are these the intended consequences of crossover, or am I
> > missin=
g
> >>>>>>>>> something?
> >>>>>>>>>> 
> >>>>>>>>>> Cheers,
> >>>>>>>>>> Je=
ff Clune

niversity

    <P>Initial results from r=
unning with crossover working as you 
    described<BR>look worse than with=
 the old way; however, I think that the 
    mutation<BR>rates need to be t=
weaked because now mutations in individuals 
    quickly<BR>spread througho=
ut the species.<BR><BR>I'm going to try to play 
    with the mutation rate=
s and see if I can get<BR>it to work better, but I 
    think it might actu=
ally work better without<BR>performing crossover on each 
    gene.<BR><BR>=
I'll let you know what I find out.<BR><BR>Jason G.<BR><BR>--- 
    In <A hr=

   > Subject: [neat] Re: Crossover doing anything in HyperNEAT and 
    =
PNEAT?<BR>> > <BR>> > The question about crossover in NEAT is 
=
    interesting. Although it does<BR>> > not provide a huge boost in =

    performance, it is still a significant<BR>> > advance compared t=
o what 
    came before in neuroevolution, which is why<BR>> > it is =
still a 
    payoff. The competing conventions problem (also called<BR>>=
 > the 
    "topology matching problem") was a huge issue in neuroevolut=
ion<BR>> > 
    before NEAT, and because of it some researchers were =
questioning<BR>> 
    > whether there was any hope for crossover at a=
ll in such systems. 
    It<BR>> > could be shown in prior systems wi=
thout historical marking 
    that<BR>> > crossover actually hurts th=
e evolution of neural networks, 
    making its<BR>> > prospects dim.=
 Angeline and Pollack even introduced 
    a neuroevolution<BR>> > me=
thod called GNARL (before NEAT) that didn't 
    even have crossover as<BR>=
> > an operator because of the concern. In 
    this context, NEAT ma=
de<BR>> > crossover safe for neuroevolution and 
    removed its stig=
ma in such<BR>> > systems. That is, it switched it 
    from a liabil=
ity to an advantage<BR>> > that boosts performance a bit 
    in NEAT=
. So it's an advance in that<BR>sense.<BR>> > <BR>> > 
    Howe=
ver, while the "bit" of performance gain (vs. having no 
    crossover)<BR>=
> > *is* likely statistically significant, it is not 
    huge. The r=
eal<BR>> > benefit of historical markings<BR>> > is 
    that i=
t enables speciation, which does have a dramatic effect<BR>> > 
    b=
ecause of protecting innovation to support complexification.<BR>> > 
=
    Crossover is more like icing on the cake. However, I think many<BR>>=
 > 
    people identify NEAT with crossover because it is such a clear<B=
R>> > 
    demonstration of the benefit of historical markings. In th=
at sense,<BR>> 
    > it is perhaps conceptually more significant tha=
n it is 
    functionally.<BR>> > Still, I would recommend keeping it=
 if you can, 
    since it does appear<BR>> > to be better to have it=
 than not, albeit 
    not enormously.<BR>> > <BR>> > ken<BR>&g=
t; > <BR>> >
